Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Yeah, sure.

Dialogue: I'll call her up.

Dialogue: You call her up for yourself, Angie. I don't feel like calling her up.

Dialogue: How about going downa Seventy-Second Street, see what we can find? Ralph says you have to beat them off with clubs.

Speaker: angie
Dialogue: Boy, you're getting to be a real drag, you know that?

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Angie, I'm thirty-four years old. I been looking for a girl every Saturday night of my life. I'm tired of looking. Everybody's always telling me to get married. Get married. Get married. Don't you think I wanna get married? I wanna get married. They drive me crazy. Now, I don't wanna wreck your Saturday night for you, Angie. You wanna go somewhere, you go ahead. I don't wanna go.

Speaker: angie
Dialogue: My old lady, every word outta her mouth, when you gonna get married?

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: My mother, boy, she drives me crazy.

Speaker: angie
Dialogue: So what do you feel like doing tonight?

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: I don't know. What do you feel like doing?

Dialogue: Marty, your mother wants you onna phone.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Hello, Ma, what's the matter?

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: I'm coming home right now, Ma. I'll be home in about two minutes. Tell Thomas stick around, I wanna see him about something.

Speaker: virginia
Dialogue: So what happened, Aunt Theresa, about the milk bottle was my mother-in- law, she comes inna kitchen, Aunt Theresa, and she begins poking her head over my shoulder here and poking her head over my shoulder there, so then she begins telling me how I waste money and how I can't cook, and how I'm raising my baby all wrong, so she got me so nervous, I spilled some milk I was making for the baby...

Speaker: virginia
Dialogue: So she say, "You're spilling the milk." So she kept talking about these coupla drops of milk I spilled, so she got me so mad, so I said, "Mama, you wanna see me really spill some milk?" So I took the bottle, and I threw it against the door. I didn't throw it at her. That's just something she made up. She goes around telling everybody I threw the bottla milk at her. I didn't throw it anywheres near her. Well, I was sorry right away, you know, but she ran outta the house.

Speaker: thomas
Dialogue: Well, I'll tell you, Aunt Theresa...

Speaker: virginia
Dialogue: Lemme tell it, Tommy.

Speaker: thomas
Dialogue: Okay.

Speaker: virginia
Dialogue: We want you to do a very big favor for us, Aunt Theresa.

Speaker: virginia
Dialogue: Aunt Theresa, you got this big house here. I mean, you got this big house just for you and Marty. And I thought maybe Tommy's mother could come here and live with you and Marty.

Speaker: virginia
Dialogue: Because I called up Tommy's brother Joe, and I said, "Joe, she's driving me crazy. Why don't you take her for a couple of years?" And he said, "Oh no!" I know I sound like a terrible woman...

Speaker: virginia
Dialogue: I just can't stand it any more! Every minute of the day! Do this! Do that! I don't have ten minutes privacy with my husband! We can't even have a fight! We don't have no privacy! Everybody's miserable in our house!

Speaker: thomas
Dialogue: All right, Ginnie, don't get so excited.

Speaker: thomas
Dialogue: That's very nice-a you, Aunt Theresa.

Speaker: thomas
Dialogue: Sure.

Speaker: virginia
Dialogue: That's very nice-a you, Aunt Theresa.

Speaker: thomas
Dialogue: How's Marty been lately, Aunt Theresa?

Speaker: thomas
Dialogue: Oh, he'll get married, don't worry, Aunt Theresa.

Speaker: thomas
Dialogue: Well, there's the Stardust Ballroom. That's a kind of a big dance hall. Every Saturday night, it's just loaded with girls. It's a nice place to go. You pay seventy-seven cents. It used to be seventy-seven cents. It must be about a buck and half now. And you go in and you ask some girl to dance. That's how I met Virginia. Nice, respectable place to meet girls. You tell Marty, Aunt Theresa, you tell him, "Go to the Stardust Ballroom. It's loaded with tomatoes."

Speaker: thomas
Dialogue: Right.

Speaker: virginia
Dialogue: This is very nice-a you, Aunt Theresa, what you're doing for us, and don't think we don't appreciate...

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Hello, Ma.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Sure, Ma, it's okay with me.

Speaker: thomas
Dialogue: Oh, Marty, thanks a lot. That really takes a load offa my mind.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Oh, we got plenny-a room here.

Speaker: thomas
Dialogue: I just wanna thank you people again, because the situation was just becoming impossible.

Speaker: virginia
Dialogue: I'm sorry we gotta rush like this...

Speaker: virginia
Dialogue: On accounta...

Speaker: thomas
Dialogue: Marty, I don't know how to tell you how much I appreciate what you and your mother are doing, because the kinda thing was happening in our house was Virginia was in the kitchen making some milk for the baby. So my mother comes in...

Speaker: virginia
Dialogue: Tommy, I promised the babysitter six o'clock.

Dialogue: Tommy, before you go, I wonder if you gimme a little advice.

Speaker: thomas
Dialogue: Sure, what?

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: You're the accountant inna family, and I figure you might know about these things. My boss wantsa sell his shop to me. His kids are all married, you know, and he and his wife live alone, and they wanna move out to California where his daughter lives, so he wantsa sell his shop. He wants five thousand dollars down, although I think I can knock him downa four...

Speaker: virginia
Dialogue: Tommy!

Speaker: thomas
Dialogue: I'll see you at mass tomorrow. We'll sit down and we'll discuss the whole thing.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: All right, I'll see you, Thomas, because he wants an answer by Monday.

Speaker: thomas
Dialogue: Sure. Thanks a lot about my mother. We'll work out some arrangement, because naturally I want to pay...

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Don't worry about it.

Speaker: thomas
Dialogue: No, listen, that's my mother, I'm gonna pay for her...

Speaker: virginia
Dialogue: Goodby, Marty!

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Goodby, Virginia! See you soon!

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Hello, is this Mary Feeney?... Could I speak to Miss Mary Feeney?... Just tell her an old friend...

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: ...Oh, hello there, is this Mary Feeney? Hello there, this is Marty Pilletti. I wonder if you recall me... Well, I'm kind of a stocky guy. The last time we met was in a movie, the RKO Chester. You was with another girl, and I was with a friend of mine named Angie. This was about a month ago...

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: The RKO Chester in Westchester Square. You was sitting in front of us, and we was annoying you, and you got mad, and... I'm the fellow who works in a butcher shop... Come on, you know who I am!... That's right, we went to Howard Johnson's and we had hamburgers. You hadda milkshake... Yeah, that's right. I'm the stocky one, the heavy-set feller... Well, I'm glad you recall me, because I hadda swell time that night, and I was just wondering how everything was with you. How's everything?... That's swell... Yeah, well, I'll tell you why I called...I was figuring on taking in a movie tonight, and I was wondering if you and your friend would care to see a movie tonight with me and my friend...  Yeah, tonight. I know it's pretty late to call for a date, but I didn't know myself, till... Yeah, I know, well how about... Yeah, I know, well maybe next Saturday night. You free next Saturday night?... Well, how about the Saturday after that?... Yeah, I know... Yeah... Yeah... Oh, I understand, I mean...

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: I don't know, Ma. I'm all knocked out. I may just hang arounna house.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: It's loaded with what?

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Ha! Who told you about the Stardust Ballroom?

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Oh, Thomas. Ma, it's just a big dance hall, and that's all it is. I been there a hundred times. Loaded with tomatoes. Boy, you're funny, Ma.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Ma, when are you gonna give up? You gotta bachelor on your hands. I ain't never gonna get married.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Sooner or later, there comes a point in a man's life when he gotta face some facts, and one fact I gotta face is that whatever it is that women like, I ain't got it. I chased enough girls in my life. I went to enough dances. I got hurt enough. I don't wanna get hurt no more. I just called a girl just now, and I got a real brush-off, boy. I figured I was past the point of being hurt, but that hurt. Some stupid woman who I didn't even wanna call up. She gave me the brush. I don't wanna go to the Stardust Ballroom because all that ever happened to me there was girls made me feel like I was a bug. I got feelings, you know. I had enough pain. No, thank you.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Ma, I'm gonna stay home and watch Jackie Gleason.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: So I'll die without a son.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Blue suit, gray suit, I'm still a fat man. A fat ugly man.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: I'm ugly... I'm ugly! I'm UGLY!

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Ma! Leave me alone!

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Ma, waddaya want from me?! Waddaya want from me?! I'm miserable enough as it is! Leave me alone! I'll go to the Stardust Ballroom! I'll put onna blue suit and I'll go! And you know what I'm gonna get for my trouble? Heartache! A big night of heartache!

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Loaded with tomatoes...boy, that's rich.

Dialogue: I told you she wasn't especially attractive, but that she had a good deal of charm, and she's really a real nice girl...

Speaker: andy
Dialogue: I told you she wasn't attractive...

Dialogue: Millie's been after me to fix her up with a date, so I...

Dialogue: I'm just here with another girl.

Dialogue: I'll see you.

Dialogue: Boy, it's packed in here.

Dialogue: I wouldn't think so. I teach out in Brooklyn.

Dialogue: You been up here before, Clara?

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: Yeah, twice.

Dialogue: Hey, Herbie...

Dialogue: Hey, Herbie...

Dialogue: You wanna have a drink before we start dancing?

Dialogue: So what do you say, Clara? Wanna see if we can get a table?

Dialogue: All right.

Dialogue: There was one nice-looking one there inna black dress and beads, but she's dancing now.

Speaker: angie
Dialogue: Down there. That little one there.

Dialogue: Yeah, she looks all right from here.

Dialogue: Well, waddaya say, you wanna ask them? I'll take the one inna green dress.

Dialogue: I think this number is a little fast. Wait a minute.

Dialogue: It's all right, I think. They still there?

Dialogue: Waddaya say, you wanna dance?

Dialogue: Excuse me, would you care for this dance?

Dialogue: Sure.

Dialogue: You say something?

Dialogue: I'm stag.

Dialogue: What?

Dialogue: Are you kidding?

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: You can't just walk off onna girl like that.

Dialogue: Look, Mac, you paid me the five bucks. I was willing. It's my five bucks...

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Excuse me, Miss, would you care to dance?

Speaker: virginia
Dialogue: Hello, Aunt Theresa. Come in.

Speaker: virginia
Dialogue: We didn't tell her anything yet. We thought that we'd leave it to you. We thought you'd put it like how you were lonely, and why don't she come to live with you. Because that way it looks like she's doing you a favor, insteada we're throwing her out, and it won't be so cruel on her. Do you want Tommy and me to stay here with you?

Speaker: thomas
Dialogue: Hello, Aunt Theresa.

Speaker: thomas
Dialogue: I just this minute got the baby to sleep.

Speaker: thomas
Dialogue: Aunt Theresa, we figure the best way to ask her is you say that you're very lonely, see? And wouldn't she come and keep you company, because that way, you see...

Speaker: catherine's voice
Dialogue: Who's there?! Who's there?!

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: Hey! What are you doing here?

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: I gotta pain in my left side, and my leg throbs like a drum.

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: I gotta pains in my shoulder too. I have a pain in my hip, and my right arm aches so much I can't sleep. It's a curse to be old. How you feel?

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: That's nice.

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: That's nice. I gotta letter from my husband's cousin in Abruzzi. His mother died.

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: Do you remember Emilio DiGiorgio, owned the tavern in Abruzzi?

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: Well, he died. You know who else died?

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: You know the old man upstairs in this house. Old Irishman, always drunk. He got pleurisy. He was inna hospital two weeks. He died yesterday.

Speaker: thomas
Dialogue: Ma, you want something to eat, some tuna fish?

Speaker: virginia
Dialogue: Listen, let's go downa Kaplans' apartment. They told us to come down.

Speaker: thomas
Dialogue: All right, Ma, we're going downstairs to the Kaplans, if you want us for anything.

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: I wake up this morning, I hear the baby crying. So I wake up. I come in their room. That girl is shaking her hand atta baby. I said, "You brute! Don't you strike that baby! That's my son's baby!"

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: That's my son Thomas's baby.

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: Did I tell you she threw the bottle- a milk at me?

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: She's a witch, that one. I tell you what happen yesterday?

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: She gave me the evil eye.

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: I keep one eye open when I sleep, because she's gonna come in, stab me in my bed.

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: Ah?

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: Who?

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: When was this?

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: What they say?

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: My son Thomas came to see you this afternoon, and he said to you he wants to cast his mother from his house?

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: So I am an old garbage bag, put inna street.

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: It pains that they should do this.

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: These are the worst years, I tell you.

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: These are the worst years. I tell you. It's gonna happen to you. I'm afraida look inna mirror. I'm afraid I'm gonna see an old lady with white hair, like the old ladies inna park, little bundles inna black shawl, waiting for the coffin. I'm fifty- six years old. What am I to do with myself? I have strength in my hands. I wanna cook. I wanna clean. I wanna make dinner for my children. Am I an old dog to lie in fronta the fire til my eyes close? These are the terrible years, Theresa! Terrible years!

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: It's gonna happen to you! It's gonna happen to you! What will you do if Marty gets married?! What will you cook? What happen to alla children playing in alla rooms? Where is the noise?! It is a curse to be a widow! A curse. What will you do if Marty gets married?! What will you do?

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: I will put my clothes inna bag, and I will come to you tomorrow.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: You come up here often?

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: I was up here twice before. Once with a friend of mine and once I came up alone. The last time... do you see that girl in the gray dress sitting over there?

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Yeah.

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: Well, the last time I was up here, that's where I sat. I sat there for an hour and a half, without moving a muscle. Now and then, some fellow would sort of walk up to me and then change his mind. I'll never forget just sitting there for an hour and a half with my hands in my lap. Then I began to cry, and I had to get up and go home.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: I cry a lot too. I'm a big cryer.

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: This is something recent with me, this bursting into tears at the least thing.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Oh, I cry all the time, any little thing. My brothers, my brother-in- laws, they're always telling me what a goodhearted guy I am. Well, you don't get goodhearted by accident. You get kicked around long enough, you get to be a real professor of pain. I know exactly how you feel. And I also want you to know I'm having a very good time with you now and really enjoying myself. So you see, you're not such a dog as you think you are.

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: I'm having a very good time, too.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: So there you are. So I guess I'm not such a dog as I think I am.

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: You're a very nice guy, and I don't know why some girl hasn't grabbed you off long ago.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: I don't know either. I think I'm a very nice guy. I also think I'm a pretty smart guy in my own way.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Now I figure, two people get married, and they gonna live together forty, fifty years. So it's just gotta be more than whether they're good looking or not. You tell me you think you're not very good-looking. My father was a really ugly man, but my mother adored him. She told me that she used to get so miserable sometimes, like everybody, you know? And she says my father always tried to understand. I used to see them sometimes when I was a kid, sitting in the living room, talking and talking, and I used to adore my old man, because he was so kind. That's one of the most beautiful things I have in my life, the way my father and mother were. And my father was a real ugly man. So it doesn't matter if you look like a gorilla. So you see, dogs like us, we ain't such dogs as we think we are.

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: I'm twenty-nine years old. How old are you?

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: I'm thirty-four.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: ...you teach chemistry? That's funny. Where? What school?

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: Benjamin Franklin High School.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Benjamin Franklin, where's that? Brooklyn? I went to Theodore Roosevelt right up here on Fordham Road. It's right arounna corner from my house. I have a cousin who's a teacher. He teaches Latin. He lives in Chicago. He was studying to be a Jesuit, but he gave it up after his first vows.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: I was pretty good in high school. I sound like a jerk now, but I was pretty good. I graduated with an eighty-two average. That ain't bad. I was accepted at City College. I filled out the application and everything, but my old man died, so I hadda go to work. My best class was German. That was my first language. Der, die, das -- des, der, des. There you are, I still remember...

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: You know what I was good at in high school? I was good in Math. You know how long ago I graduated high school? June, nineteen-thirty-seven. Holy cow! June, nineteen-thirty-seven! What is that? Fifteen, seventeen years ago! Holy cow! Seventeen years ago! Is that right? Seventeen, that's right. Where did it all go? I'm getting old. I'm gonna be thirty- five November eighth. Thirty-five. Wow. Time goes on, boy.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Nineteen-thirty-seven... that's right. My old man died December, nineteen- thirty-seven.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Two o'clock in the morning he died. The doorbell rings, and I knew something was wrong right away. Because my room is onna ground floor inna front, you see, and I got outta bed, and I answered the door...

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: There was Mr. Stern. He had a house down about a block from us. He moved out though. My old man, he used to play cards with him and some other old guys. He's a Jewish feller. So he said, "Is your mother home?" So I knew right away there was something wrong. I was only eighteen, exactly eighteen years old, just the month before. So I said, "Is something wrong, Mr. Stern?" I was in my pajamas, you know? So he said, "Marty, your father died." My father died right inna middle of playing cards, right at the table. He had a heart attack. He had low blood pressure, my old man. He used to faint a lot.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Boy, am I talking, I never talked so much in my life. Usually, everybody comes to me and tells me all their troubles. Well, I'm gonna shut up now, and I'm gonna let you get a word in...

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Seventeen years ago. What I been doing with myself all that time?... Well, I'm talking again. I must be driving you crazy. Mosta the time I'm with a girl, I can't find a word to say. Well, I'm gonna shut up now. Because I'm not like this usually. Usually, I... well, here I go again.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: I can't shut my mouth... I'm on a jag, for Pete's sake. You'd think I was loaded...

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: I can't stop talking! Isn't this stupid?!

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: You gotta real nice face, you know? It's really a nice face.

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: ...so I'm inna kneeling position, and if you ever try shooting a BAR inna kneeling position, you know what I mean. I can't holda steady position. I'm wavering back and forth...

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: ...so the guy next to me, he's shooting from the prone position, and he's cross-eyed like I told you...

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: So just then...  ...so just then I hear five shots go off from the guy next to me...

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: So my target goes down, and a minute later, the flag comes up. I got five bulls-eyes. This cross-eyed guy next to me, he shot five bulls-eyes into my target...

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: ...so I said to the sergeant who was checking my score, "Pretty good, eh, Sarge? Five bulls-eyes? So this sergeant, he don't know what happened, he says, "Say, that's all right, Pilletti"...

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Oh, man. So that's what happened. That's how I got the reputation-a being the best shot inna whole battalion... oh, man...

Speaker: bucko
Dialogue: Anything good in there, Mac?

Speaker: angie
Dialogue: A buncha dogs.

Speaker: angie
Dialogue: Hey, Marty! Hey, Marty, you in here?!

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: ...When I got outta the army, Clara, I was lost. I didn't know what I wanted to do. I was twenny-five years old, what was I gonna do, go back to my old job, forty cents an hour. I thought maybe I go to college under the G.I. Biller Rights, you know? But I wouldn't graduate till I was twenny-eight, twenny-nine years old, even if I made it in three years. And my brother Freddie wanted to get married, and I had three unmarried sisters -- in an Italian home, that's a terrible thing. And my kid brother Nickie, he's a one got married last week. So I just went to pieces. I used to walk inna streets till three, four o'clock inna mornings. My mother used to be so worried about me. My uncle Mario come over one time. He offered me a job driving his hack onna night shift. He got his own cab, you know. And God forgive me for what I'm gonna say now, but I used to thinka doing away with myself. I used to stand sometimes in the subway, and God forgive me what I'm going to say, I used to feel the tracks sucking me down under the wheels.

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: Yes, I know.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: I'm a Catholic, you know, and even to think about suicide is a terrible sin.

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: Yes, I know.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: So then Mr. Gazzara -- he was a frienda my father -- he offered me this job in his butcher shop, and everybody pleaded with me to take it. So that's what happened. I didn't wanna be a butcher.

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: There's nothing wrong with being a butcher.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Well, I wouldn't call it an elegant profession. It's in a lower social scale. People look down on butchers.

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: I don't.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Well, the point is Mr. Gazzara wantsa sell his shop now, because he and his wife are lonely, and they wanna move out to California in Los Angeles and live near their married daughter. Because she's always writing them to come out there. So it's a nice little shop. I handle his books for him, so I know he has a thirty-five percent markup which is not unreasonable, and he takes home net maybe a hundred, hundred and fifty bucks a week. The point is, of course, you gotta worry about the supermarkets. There's two inna neighborhood now, and there's an A&P coming in, at least that's the rumor. Of course, mosta his trade is strictly Italian, but the younger Italian girls, they get married, and they don't stick to the old Italian dishes so much. I mean, you gotta take that into account too.

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: It's my feeling that you really want to buy this shop, Marty.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: That's true. I do. But I'm gonna have to take outta loan inna bank eight thousand dollars. That's a big note to carry, because I have to give Mr. Gazzara a mortgage, and what I have to weigh is: will it pay off in the end more than I can make onna salary?

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: Marty, I know you for three hours, but I know you're a good butcher. You're an intelligent, sensitive, decent man. I have a feeling about you like sometimes a kid comes in to see me for one reason or another. And some of these kids, Marty, in my classes, they have so much warmth in them, so much capacity. And that's the feeling I get about you.

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: If you were one of my students, I would say, "Go ahead and buy the butcher shop. You're a good butcher."

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Well, there's a lotta things I could do with this shop. I could organize my own supermarket. Get a buncha neighborhood merchants together. That's what a lotta them are doing.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Wadda you think?

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: I think anything you want to do, you'll do well.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: I'm Catholic. Are you Catholic?

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: Yes, I am.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: I only got about three bucks on me now, but I just live about eight blocks from here on the other side of Webster Avenue. Why don't we walk back to my house? I'll run in, pick up some dough, and let's step out somewhere.

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: I really should get home...

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: It's only a quarter of twelve. The clock's right over there.

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: I really should get home, I told my father... Well, I suppose a little while longer. I wonder if there's any place around here I could put some makeup on...

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Hey, Mac!

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: You gotta Ladies' Room around here?

Speaker: proprietor
Dialogue: Inna back.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Inna back.

Speaker: angie
Dialogue: Hey, Lou!

Speaker: angie
Dialogue: Hey, Lou!

Speaker: bartender
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: angie
Dialogue: Marty been in here the last coupla hours or so?

Speaker: bartender
Dialogue: I ain't seen Marty all night...

Speaker: angie
Dialogue: Where is everybody? I been walking around, I can't find anybody...

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: ...It's really a fine opportunity for me. But I'm not sure I want to be a department head. It's mostly executive and administrative work. Well, anyway, I told you about my father, and he depends on me a great deal, and...

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Why don't you just move out to Portchester?

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: Well, that's what I was saying. My father is getting old. And we're very close. He's a wonderful man, really...

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: I think you're kidding yourself, Clara. I used to think about moving out, you know? And that's what I used to say. "My mother needs me." But when you really get down to it, that ain't it at all. Actually, you need your father. You know what I mean? You're living at home, and you got your father and mother there, and you can go on like that -- being a little girl all your life.

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: I'm afraid of being lonely.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Oh, you won't be so lonely. You'll make friends right away.

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: Actually, I don't make friends easily.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: What're you talking about? You're a real likeable person. You'll make friends out there in Portchester one, two, three. You'll have people visiting you alla time. I'll come visit you. I'll borrow my brother Freddie's car, or you can call me up when you feel blue, or I'll call you up. And it's gonna be nice. Don't be so afraid.

Speaker: ralph's voice
Dialogue: Hey, Marty!

Speaker: ralph
Dialogue: Hey, Marty!

Speaker: ralph
Dialogue: Marty! Over here!

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Hello, Ralph.

Speaker: ralph
Dialogue: Hey, Marty, come over here a minute.

Speaker: ralph
Dialogue: You'll like this guy. This guy's a nice guy.

Speaker: leo
Dialogue: Who's this? Marty?

Speaker: ralph
Dialogue: Yeah.

Speaker: leo
Dialogue: Oh, this guy's a nice guy.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Hiya, Leo.

Speaker: leo
Dialogue: Hiya, Marty.

Speaker: ralph
Dialogue: Hey, Marty, come here a minute.

Speaker: ralph
Dialogue: Hey, Marty, we got an odd squirrel here, you interested?

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Waddaya mean, Ralph?

Speaker: ralph
Dialogue: Hey, Louise, I want you to meet Marty Pilletti. Marty, that's Louise Kelly, inna back seat there.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Hiya.

Speaker: louise
Dialogue: What are we going to do, just sit around here all night?

Speaker: ralph
Dialogue: Listen, Marty, these three squirrels are nurses. We're all going over Leo's house later because there's nobody there. These are the squirrels I told you about. Money inna bank, man. Wanna get inna car? She's a pretty nice-looking doll.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: I'm with a girl, Ralph.

Speaker: ralph
Dialogue: Get ridda her. This is money inna bank.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: I can't do that, Ralph, because somebody already brushed her off once tonight.

Speaker: ralph
Dialogue: This is a good deal here, Marty.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Very nice to have met you all.

Speaker: louise
Dialogue: Come on, let's get outta here.

Speaker: leo
Dialogue: Hey, Ralph, we might as well get going.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: I'll see you, Leo.

Speaker: leo
Dialogue: I'll see you, Marty.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Wait a minute. Lemme find the light.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: I guess my mother ain't home yet. I figure my cousin Thomas and Virginia musta gone to the movies, so they won't get back till one o'clock at least.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: This is the kitchen.

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: Yes, I know.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Come on inna dining room.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Siddown, take off your coat. You want something to eat? We gotta whole half-chicken in the icebox.

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: No, thank you. I don't think I should stay very long.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Sure. Just take off your coat a minute.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: So I was telling you, my kid brother Nickie got married last Sunday. That was a very nice affair. And they had this statue of some woman, and they had whiskey spouting outta her mouth. I never saw anything so grand in my life.  And watta meal. I'm a butcher, so I know a good hunka steak when I see one. That was choice filet, right off the toppa the chuck. A buck eighty a pound. Of course, if you wanna cheaper cut, get rib steak. That gotta lotta waste on it, but it comes to about a buck and a quarter a pound, if it's trimmed. Listen, Clara, make yourself comfortable. You're all tense.

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: Oh, I'm fine.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: You want me to take you home, I'll take you home.

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: Maybe that would be a good idea.

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: No, Marty, please...

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: I like you. I like you. I been telling you all night, I like you...

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: Marty...

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: I just wanna kiss, that's all.

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: No...

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Please...

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: No...

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Please...

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: Marty...

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: All right! I'll take you home! All right!

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: All I wanted was a lousy kiss! What do you think, I was gonna try something serious with my mother coming home any minute!? What am I, a leper or something?!

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: I just didn't feel like it, that's all.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: I'm old enough to know better. Comes New Year's Eve, everybody starts arranging parties, I'm the guy they gotta dig up a date for. Let me getta packa cigarettes, and I'll take you home.

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: I'd like to see you again. Very much. The reason I didn't let you kiss me was because I just didn't know how to handle the situation. You're the kindest man I ever met. The reason I tell you this is because I want to see you again very much. I know that when you take me home, I'm going to just lie on my bed and think about you. I want very much to see you again.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Waddaya doing tomorrow night?

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: Nothing.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: I'll call you up tomorrow morning. Maybe, we'll go see a movie.

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: I'd like that very much.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: The reason I can't be definite about it now is my Aunt Catherine is probably coming over tomorrow, and I may have to help out.

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: I'll wait for your call.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: We better get started to your house, because the buses only run about one an hour now.

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: All right.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: I'll just get a packa cigarettes.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Waddaya doing New Year's Eve?

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: Nothing.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: We just got here about fifteen minutes ago. Ma, I want you to meet Miss Clara Snyder. She's graduate of New York University. She teaches chemistry in Benjamin Franklin High School.

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: No, Mrs. Pilletti. We were just going home. Thank you very much anyway.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: How'd you come home, Ma? Thomas give you a ride?

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Oh, she's coming, eh, Ma?

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Might as well siddown a minute, Clara.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: I offered her, Ma, she don't want nothing.

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: No, thank you, really, Mrs. Pilletti.

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: Couldn't she find some sort of hobby to fill out her time?

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: You mustn't feel too harshly against her daughter-in-law. She also wants to have a house to clean and a family to cook for.

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: Well, I don't know the people, of course, but as a rule, I don't think a mother-in-law should live with a young couple.

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: I don't think a mother should depend so much upon her children for her rewards in life.

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: It's silly of me to argue about it. I don't know the people involved.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Ma, I'm gonna take her home now. It's getting late, and the buses only run about one an hour.

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: It was very nice meeting you, Mrs. Pilletti. I hope I'll see you again.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: All right, Ma. I'll be back in about an hour, an hour anna half.

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: Goodnight, Mrs. Pilletti.

Speaker: angie
Dialogue: Hey!!

Speaker: angie
Dialogue: Hey!

Speaker: angie
Dialogue: Hey, Marty! Hey!

Speaker: angie's voice
Dialogue: Hey, Marty! Marty!

Speaker: angie
Dialogue: Where you been, for Pete sakes?! I been looking all over for you.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: I looked for you, Angie, before I cut out, but I couldn't find you.

Speaker: angie
Dialogue: I been looking all over for you!

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: What happened, Angie, was that we thought we were just gonna go for a short walk, and then we thought we were gonna come right back, but we got to talking. Listen, Angie, I want you to meet Clara...  Clara, this is my best friend, Angie. I told you about him.

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: How do you do?

Speaker: angie
Dialogue: Waddaya gonna do now?

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: I'm gonna take Clara home. It's close to one.

Speaker: angie
Dialogue: You want me to ride down with you?

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: What for?

Speaker: angie
Dialogue: It's early.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: It must be one o'clock.

Speaker: angie
Dialogue: It's Saturday night! There's still plenty-a action around!

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Angie, by the time I get Clara home, it's gonna be one, one-thirty. By the time I get home, it's gonna be two o'clock. I gotta get up for ten o'clock mass tomorrow.

Speaker: angie
Dialogue: All right, I'll see you!

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Where you going?

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: I'll see you tomorrow after mass!

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: You got an elevator in this house?

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: We just live one flight up.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: So I'll call you tomorrow.

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: Okay.

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: Call me about two-thirty, because I won't be home from my aunt's till about then.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Okay, so I'll see you tomorrow night then.

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: Okay.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Taxi! Taxi! Hey, taxi! Taxi! Taxi!

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Taxi!... Taxi!...

Speaker: virginia
Dialogue: Don't you think I feel lousy about this too?

Speaker: thomas
Dialogue: All right, Ginnie. I don't wanna talk anymore about it.  Last night was the first time in my life I ever heard my mother cry, you know that?

Speaker: virginia
Dialogue: Tommy...

Speaker: thomas
Dialogue: I don't wanna talk about it!

Speaker: thomas
Dialogue: I know what you're gonna say. A man's gotta stop being his mother's baby sooner or later. How many times you gonna say it? She's my mother, you know. I oughta have some feelings about her, don't you think?

Speaker: virginia
Dialogue: Why do you always put me inna position of being the louse?

Speaker: thomas
Dialogue: Virginia, I don't wanna hear no more about it!

Speaker: virginia
Dialogue: Tommy, I love you, and I know you feel lousy right now, but we're never gonna be happy unless we have a chance to work out our own lives. We can't keep talking in whispers like this the resta our lives. We gotta have some privacy. We...

Speaker: thomas
Dialogue: Can't you wait five minutes? I'll drive you over inna car. I just gotta put my shirt on, that's all.

Speaker: thomas
Dialogue: All right, get dressed, because we're gonna drive my mother over. Why couldn't you get along with her?! Why couldn't you make just a little effort?! She's a little hard to get along with! All right! All I asked you was try a little.

Speaker: virginia
Dialogue: Tommy...

Speaker: thomas
Dialogue: I don't wanna hear anymore about it, you hear me?

Speaker: thomas
Dialogue: Hello, Aunt Theresa.

Speaker: thomas
Dialogue: Ah, my mother, she drives me crazy. I hadda beg her to let me drive her over here. The martyr. She always gotta be the big martyr.

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: Hey, will you go to mass, please. This one, he woke up this morning with salt in his nose. Do this! Do that! Will you leave me in peace, ah?

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Hello, Aunt Catherine! How are you? Hello, Thomas. You going to mass with us?

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: I was at mass two hours ago.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Well, make yourself at home. The refrigerator is loaded with food. Go upstairs, take any room you want. Thomas, you going to mass with us?

Speaker: thomas
Dialogue: Yeah, yeah, sure.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Boy, beautiful day, hey, Thomas?

Speaker: thomas
Dialogue: Sure, great if you ain't married.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Hi, Virginia.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Hey, Thomas, so I was telling you yesterday you was over my house -- Mr. Gazzara, my boss, so he wantsa sell his shop, go out to California because his kids are all married, and he...

Speaker: thomas
Dialogue: Wadda you so sore about?

Speaker: virginia
Dialogue: Oh shaddup, will you do me a favor?

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: So Thomas, he does about twelve, thirteen hundred gross. Rent's a hundred and two. The problem, of course, is the supermarkets. That's what I wanna ask you. If I get together with a coupla other merchants, make our own supermarket...

Speaker: thomas
Dialogue: What about the time she wanted to make an old-fashioned Italian dinner for my brother, but you wouldn't let her!?

Speaker: virginia
Dialogue: Waddaya talking about?!!

Speaker: thomas
Dialogue: Once a month you couldn't let her use the kitchen!

Speaker: virginia
Dialogue: I told her she could use the kitchen any time she wanted...

Speaker: thomas
Dialogue: ...You hadda be the boss inna kitchen alla time!

Speaker: virginia
Dialogue: She don't wanna use my pots and pans!

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: So Tommy...

Speaker: virginia
Dialogue: Waddaya want me to do, go out and buy a whole new setta pots and pans?!

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Tommy, gimme a coupla minutes, because I promised Mr. Gazzara I'd let him know tomorrow. See, what I wanna know, Tom, if a buncha individual retail merchants get together, how does it operate? On individual mark- ups? You know what I mean? Say I'm the butcher and Aldo Capelli, he's the dairyman and grocer, so suppose I mark up thirty-five percent, but he works on forty, so...

Speaker: thomas
Dialogue: Waddaya talking about, do you know what you're talking about?

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: No, I don't know. That's why I'm asking you.

Speaker: thomas
Dialogue: Take the baby, will you?!

Speaker: thomas
Dialogue: Wadda you wanna buy a shop for, will you tell me? You gotta good job, you got no wife, you got no responsibilities. Boy, I wish I was you, boy. Waddaya wanna tie yourself down with a shop? What's he want? Five thousand down? You're gonna have to carry a mortgage sixty, seventy bucks a month. A mortgage anna note from the bank. For Pete's sake, you're a single man with no responsibilities. Stay that way, boy. Take my advice.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Well, you see, Thomas I figure the big problem is the supermarkets. But Patsy's shop, that's a specialized trade. The supermarkets don't carry Italian meat.

Speaker: thomas
Dialogue: Who buys Italian meat anymore? You think my wife buys Italian meat?  She goes to the A&P, picks up some lamb chops wrapped in cellophane, opens up a canna peas, and that's dinner, boy.

Speaker: virginia
Dialogue: Sure, all you wanna eat is that greasy stuff your mother makes.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Well, I understand the problem about the supermarkets, but I was talking to this girl last night, and she made the point that a likeable personality is a valuable business asset.

Speaker: thomas
Dialogue: Marty, see that my mother is nice and comfortable, eh?

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Sure. This girl said...

Speaker: thomas
Dialogue: What girl, what does she know?  Why don't you let her hold the baby once in a while?! Your mother, boy, she wantsa take the kid for a day, that's fine!

Speaker: virginia
Dialogue: Your mother handles the kid like he was a yoyo!

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: Who?

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: Your son Marty?

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: Were the lights on?

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: They're the worst. College girls are one step from the streets. They smoke like men inna saloon. My son Joseph, his wife, you know, she types onna typewriter. One step from the streets, I tell you. Mrs. Pilletti ponders this philosophy for a moment.

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: Well, that's all. You will see. Today, tomorrow, inna week, he's gonna say to you, "Hey, Ma, it's no good being a single man. I'm tired-a running around." Then he's gonna say, "Hey, Ma, wadda we need this old house? Why don't we sell this old house, move into a nicer parta town? A nice little apartment?"

Speaker: catherine
Dialogue: You will see. A coupla months, you gonna be an old lady, sleeping onna couch in her daughter-in-law's house.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Hello, Ma, waddaya say, it's getting a little late.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Boy, this place is really coming to pieces.  You know, Ma, I think we oughta sell this place. The whole joint's going to pieces. The plumbing is rusty. Everything. I'm gonna have to replaster the whole ceiling now. You know what we oughta do? We oughta get one of those new apartments they're building down on Southern Boulevard. A nicer parta town, you know?...You all set, Ma?

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: I heard you, Ma.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: She's twenty-nine, Ma.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: What, Ma?

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: I don't know. I don't think so.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: What are you talking about? She's a nice girl.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: You don't like her. You only met her for two minutes.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: What didn't you like about her?

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Well, let's not get inna fight about it, Ma.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: What are you getting so worked up about? I just met the girl last night. I'm probably not gonna see her again.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Hello, Lou, Angie come in yet?

Speaker: bartender
Dialogue: He was here last night till about two o'clock. I hear you really got stuck with a dog last night.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Who told you that?

Speaker: bartender
Dialogue: Angie. He says she was a real scrawny- looking thing.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: She wasn't so bad.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Hello, Ralph. How'd you make out with those nurses last night, Ralph?

Speaker: ralph
Dialogue: Oh man, you shoulda come with us last night, Marty. That one for you was a real lunatic. How'd you make out?

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Oh, I hadda nice time...I didn't try nothing. She's a nice girl. I just met her last night, you know. I just talked with her. I didn't even try nothing...

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Listen, you see Angie, tell him I went home, I'll meet him after lunch.

Speaker: joe
Dialogue: ...so the whole book winds up, Mike Hammer, he's inna room there with this doll. So he says, "You rat, you are the murderer." So she begins to con him, you know? She tells him how she loves him. And then Bam! He shoots her in the stomach. So she's laying there, gasping for breath, and she says, "How could you do that?" And he says, "It was easy."

Speaker: leo
Dialogue: Boy, that Mickey Spillane, boy he can write.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: We gotta whole pot inna kitchen. We give you a plate-a your own.

Speaker: angie
Dialogue: Oh, I couldn't eat nothing. My mother just stuffed me right up to the jaws.

Speaker: joe
Dialogue: What I like about Mickey Spillane is he knows how to handle women. In one book, he picks up a tomato who gets hit with a car, and she throws a pass at him. And then he meets two beautiful twins, and they throw passes at him. And then he meets some beautiful society leader, and she throws a pass at him, and...

Speaker: leo
Dialogue: Boy, that Mickey Spillane, he sure can write.

Speaker: angie
Dialogue: Listen, somebody turn onna ballgame. It must be after one o'clock by now.

Speaker: angie
Dialogue: Who you gonna call?

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: I was gonna call that girl from last night. Take her to a movie tonight.

Speaker: angie
Dialogue: Are you kidding?

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Listen, Angie, I wanna tell you, you were very impolite last night. I introduced you to the girl, you just turned and walked off. Now, why did you do that?

Speaker: angie
Dialogue: You got me mad, that's why. Hey, Joe, show Marty that picture.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Put that away, for Pete's sake. My mother's right out onna porch.

Speaker: joe
Dialogue: I wonder where they find those girls that pose for them pictures.

Speaker: leo
Dialogue: Those are Hollywood starlets.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Put it away, Joe. My mother'll come walking in.

Speaker: angie
Dialogue: Marty, let's go downna Seventy-Second Street area tonight.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: I don't feel like going, Angie. I thought I'd take this girl to a movie.

Speaker: angie
Dialogue: Boy, you really musta made out good last night.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: We just talked.

Speaker: angie
Dialogue: Boy, she musta been some talker. She musta been about fifty years old.

Speaker: joe
Dialogue: I always figure a guy oughta marry a girl who's twenny years younger than he is so that when he's forty, his wife is a real nice-looking doll.

Speaker: leo
Dialogue: That means he'd have to marry the girl when she was one year old.

Speaker: joe
Dialogue: I never thoughta that.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: I didn't think she was so bad-looking.

Speaker: angie
Dialogue: She musta kept you inna shadows all night.

Speaker: ralph
Dialogue: Marty, you don't wanna hang around with dogs. It gives you a bad reputation.

Speaker: angie
Dialogue: Let's go downa Seventy-Second Street.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: I told this dog I was gonna call her today about two-thirty.

Speaker: angie
Dialogue: Brush her. Listen, you wanna come with me tonight, or you wanna go with this dog?

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Waddaya getting so sore about?

Speaker: angie
Dialogue: I looked all over for you last night, you know that?

Speaker: joe
Dialogue: Another book that I read by Mickey Spillane, I can't remember the name of it, but it was about this red- headed tramp he finds inna street, and he gives her some dough, because he's sorry for her... Wait a minute, I think that's the same book I was telling you about before...

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: You didn't like her at all?

Speaker: angie
Dialogue: A nothing. A real nothing.

Speaker: joe's voice
Dialogue: You know something...?

Speaker: joe's voice
Dialogue: ...I can't tell one-a those Mickey Spillane books from the other, but he's a real good writer, though...

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: I don't know, Ma. I'm all knocked out. I think I'll just hang arounna house and watch...

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Maybe, I'll go out and see what Angie and the boys are doing...

Speaker: leo
Dialogue: What time is it?

Speaker: joe
Dialogue: About eight o'clock.

Speaker: angie
Dialogue: You don't feel like going downna Seventy-Second Street?

Speaker: george
Dialogue: It'll take an hour anna hour back, and the whole evening's gone.

Speaker: joe
Dialogue: What's playing on Fordham Road? I think there's a good picture in the Loew's Paradise.

Speaker: george
Dialogue: You guys feel like working up a game- a cards?

Speaker: angie
Dialogue: Come on, let's go down Seventy-Second Street, walk around. We're sure to wind up with something.

Speaker: joe's voice
Dialogue: I'll never forgive LaGuardia for cutting out burlesque outta New York City...

Speaker: george's voice
Dialogue: There's a burlesque in Union City. Let's go over to Union City...

Speaker: angie's voice
Dialogue: Yeah, you're the one who don't even wanna take a ride onna subway for half an hour. Now, you wanna go alla way over to Union City...

Speaker: george's voice
Dialogue: I feel like playing cards. I saw Richie Rizzo, that's what he said he felt like doing...

Speaker: joe's voice
Dialogue: I don't feel like playing cards. Waddaya feel like doing tonight, Angie?

Speaker: angie's voice
Dialogue: I don't know. Wadda you feel like doing?

Speaker: joe's voice
Dialogue: I don't know, Angie. Wadda you feel like doing?

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: "What are you doing tonight?"... "I don't know, what are you doing?!"...

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: The burlesque! Loew's Paradise! Miserable and lonely! Miserable and lonely and stupid! What am I, crazy or something?! I got something good here! What am I hanging around with you guys for?!

Speaker: angie
Dialogue: Watsa matter with you?

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: You don't like her. My mother don't like her. She's a dog, and I'm a fat, ugly little man. All I know is I hadda good time last night. I'm gonna have a good time tonight. If we have enough good times together, I'm gonna go down on my knees and beg that girl to marry me. If we make a party again this New Year's, I gotta date for the party. You don't like her, that's too bad.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: When you gonna get married, Angie? Aren't you ashamed of yourself? You're thirty-three years old. All your kid brothers are married. You oughta be ashamed of yourself.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Hello... Clara?...
